prompts: An X-ray of a giant cell tumor, a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor.
A lytic, eccentric lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone, extending to the articular surface.
Radiograph showing a geographic bone lesion with a well-defined, non-sclerotic border.
A medical scan presenting a 'soap bubble' appearance, characteristic of a giant cell tumor.
An X-ray showing multiple osteochondromas, a condition known as hereditary multiple exostoses.
Multiple bony projections with cartilage caps, typically seen in a young patient.
Radiograph showing multiple exostoses pointing away from the nearest joint.
An X-ray of an osteochondroma, a common benign bone tumor.
A cartilage-capped bony projection on the external surface of a bone, pointing away from the joint.
This radiograph shows a pedunculated or sessile lesion with cortical and medullary continuity with the host bone.
An X-ray of an osteofibrous dysplasia, a benign fibro-osseous lesion.
A well-circumscribed, intracortical, lytic lesion, typically in the tibia.
Radiograph showing a hazy, ground-glass appearance within the bone lesion.
An X-ray of a simple or unicameral bone cyst.
A centrally located, well-defined lytic lesion in the metaphysis of a long bone.
This scan shows a fluid-filled cavity with a thin sclerotic rim and may show a 'fallen fragment' sign after a fracture.
An X-ray of synovial osteochondromatosis.
Multiple small, calcified or ossified loose bodies within a joint or bursa.
Radiograph showing multiple intra-articular nodules of similar size, a condition of the synovial membrane.
An X-ray of osteosarcoma, a highly malignant bone tumor.
An aggressive, poorly defined lesion in the metaphysis, often around the knee.
Radiograph showing a 'sunburst' or 'sun-ray' periosteal reaction and bone destruction.
This scan presents a finding of Codman's triangle and production of tumor osteoid.
An X-ray of a benign bone tumor not otherwise specified.
A non-aggressive bone lesion with well-defined borders.
A focal benign process within the bone.
An X-ray of a malignant bone tumor not otherwise specified.
An aggressive bone lesion with ill-defined borders and cortical destruction.
A focal malignant process within the bone, potentially a metastasis or another primary sarcoma.
An X-ray showing disc space narrowing, a sign of degenerative disc disease.
Decreased height of the intervertebral disc space in the spine.
This radiograph shows that the space between two vertebrae is reduced.
An X-ray showing foraminal stenosis, a type of degenerative condition.
Narrowing of the neural foramen, the passageway where spinal nerves exit.
Radiograph showing encroachment on the nerve root canal due to bone spurs or disc herniation.
An X-ray showing osteophytes, also known as bone spurs.
Bony projections that form along joint margins, a sign of joint degeneration.
Li-pping of the vertebral endplates on a spinal radiograph.
An X-ray showing spondylolisthesis, a condition where one vertebra slips forward over the one below it.
Anterior displacement of a vertebra, often seen on a lateral view of the spine.
This scan shows a misalignment of the spinal column, a type of spinal instability.
An X-ray of a vertebral collapse or compression fracture.
A loss of height in the vertebral body, often resulting in a wedge shape.
This scan shows a compression deformity of a vertebra, a sign of trauma or osteoporosis.
An X-ray of a bone fracture, a type of trauma.
A clear fracture line showing a discontinuity in the bone cortex.
This medical scan presents a finding of displaced or angulated bone fragments.
An X-ray showing a surgical implant.
Presence of a high-density metallic device, such as screws, plates, or rods, used for fixation.
This radiograph shows a joint replacement or arthroplasty.
An X-ray showing a miscellaneous or other type of lesion.
An unspecified focal abnormality in the bone.
A radiographic finding that does not fit into a clear category.
A normal X-ray with no significant findings.
This radiograph shows a healthy bone and joint structure.
No evidence of fracture, dislocation, degenerative changes, or tumor.
A well-defined lesion with a sharp, clear border and a narrow zone of transition.
A non-aggressive bone lesion, often with a sclerotic (white) rim.
No signs of cortical destruction or periosteal reaction.
An ill-defined, aggressive lesion with a wide zone of transition.
A moth-eaten or permeative pattern of bone destruction.
Signs of aggressive periosteal reaction and a soft tissue mass.
An abnormal growth or mass within the bone.
A focal lesion altering the normal bone architecture.
An X-ray finding suspicious for a bone neoplasm.
Signs of joint wear and tear, such as joint space narrowing and osteophytes.
Age-related changes affecting the joints or spine.
Sclerosis and cyst formation in the subchondral bone.
Evidence of acute injury, such as a fracture or dislocation.
A break or crack in the bone caused by force.
Post-traumatic changes in bone alignment.
A miscellaneous finding, not classified as tumor, trauma, or degeneration.
A normal study or a finding like a surgical implant.
An incidental or non-specific radiographic finding.
